title: Preliminary Anti-Action
intent: Reduce risk and cost by performing preventive actions before a problem fully manifests.

triz_principle.name: Preliminary Anti-Action
triz_principle.definition: If an action is likely to cause harmful effects, introduce countermeasures in advance.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We need to move fast, but changes often introduce defects, incidents, or rework.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Fixing problems after they occur is more expensive and disruptive than preventing them early.
typical_signals: late discovery of data quality issues

solution_logic.core_idea: Anticipate likely failure modes and neutralize them before execution.
solution_logic.key_rule: Prevent the most probable damage, not all theoretical risks.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: Speed is preserved while risk is reduced through targeted, early safeguards.

consulting: early stakeholder alignment to avoid late objections
software_engineering: static analysis and linters before runtime
architecture: circuit breakers to prevent cascading failures
canary releases to detect issues early
enterprise_sap: pre-check reports before MDG change request submission
simulation and test runs before cutover activities

anti_patterns: trying to prevent every imaginable risk
heavy upfront processes that slow delivery
preventive controls disconnected from real failure modes

use_when: the same problems repeat across releases or projects
do_not_use_when: risks are unknown or highly exploratory

diagnostic_questions: What failures happen most often after changes?
Which problems are cheap to prevent but expensive to fix?
What signals could warn us earlier?

example.before: Data errors are discovered only after replication to downstream systems.
example.after: Pre-validation rules catch data issues before replication is triggered.
